page.title: 02Local History
page.content:
There are 2 possible{origins of the {name Brettenham:}The 1st is 'BRETTAS', which means British or Native 'HAM', which means settlement. The second is that 'BRET' is a family name from old Norse or Danish, which means 'bent back', perhaps referring to a deformity in the bearer of the name.
Shadwell has a handful of{cottages {inside the park,}a{well}named St. Chad's, once used by{pilgrims,}a{flint {grotto}with a{spring,}and a fine{19th {Century house}built by J J Teulon in the grounds.
Peddars Way is a Roman road. It runs from the NW Norfolk coast to the Suffolk border, passing through Brettenham. In 1907 remains perhaps of a soldiers' burial place were found to the west of the road at Brettenham.
